body.p: ∏ provides a component model, version control system, and extensive tool support for managing and delivering source code. Packages and bundles provide an organizational structure for code, as well as a model for the contents of parcels, the published version of these components.
Packages and Bundles may be versioned in a Store code repository, or saved as parcel files on your workstation. Complete documentation on Store is available in the Source Code Management Guide.
browsepackagespackagebrowsebundlebrowseThe System Browser displays the loaded packages and bundles in the upper left pane. Select the Package tab.
For bundles, expand the tree of each one to view the packages they contain.
When you select a bundle or package, the classes and name spaces contained in them are listed in the adjacent pane.
packagecreate newTo create a new package, select Package → New Package... in the System Browser. Then provide the package name.

packageadd code definitionsYou can add existing classes, name spaces, protocols, or individual methods to a package by simply selecting the item and dragging it to the package. Alternatively, select the item, pick Move → to Package... and specify the target.
To create new definitions in a package, select the package create the new object (e.g., a class). By default the definition goes into the selected package.
packagesavePackages are saved in the image. They are also the primary units stored in a Store repository.

Alternatively, you can write a package as a disk file, either as a parcel or as a file-out.
To save as a parcel, pick Package → Publish as Parecl.
To save as a file-out, pick Package → File Out → Package...

packageloadPackages are loaded into the system either from a Store repository, by loading a parcel file, or filing in a source file.
From a Store repository, select the package or bundle and a version, and pick File → Load.
From a parcel, use the Parcel Manager to find the parcel, select it, and pick File → Load.
From a source file (file-out), use the ∏ File Browser to select the file (extension .st), and pick File → File In.The code is loaded and contained in an appropriate package.

packageunloadTo unload a package, select it in the Browserâ€™s parcels view and choose Package → Remove (Unload). The contained code is removed from the system, but not from its external storage (repository or file).

packageoverride definitionsoverridebrowseDefinitions in a package may override, or be overridden by, definitions in other packages. You can browse such overrides by selecting a package, then picking Package → Browse → Overrides of others or Package → Browse → Overridden by others. If there are overrides, a conflicts browser opens so you can reconcile the code.
